speaker: GARDENER
text_entry: ACT IV

speaker: GARDENER
text_entry: SCENE I. Westminster Hall.

speaker: GARDENER
text_entry: Enter, as to the Parliament, HENRY BOLINGBROKE,  DUKE OF AUMERLE, NORTHUMBERLAND, HENRY PERCY, LORD  FITZWATER, DUKE OF SURREY, the BISHOP OF CARLISLE,  the Abbot Of Westminster, and another Lord, Herald, Officers, and BAGOT

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Call forth Bagot.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Now, Bagot, freely speak thy mind;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: What thou dost know of noble Gloucester's death,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Who wrought it with the king, and who perform'd

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: The bloody office of his timeless end.

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: Then set before my face the Lord Aumerle.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Cousin, stand forth, and look upon that man.

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: My Lord Aumerle, I know your daring tongue

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: Scorns to unsay what once it hath deliver'd.

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: In that dead time when Gloucester's death was plotted,

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: I heard you say, 'Is not my arm of length,

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: That reacheth from the restful English court

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: As far as Calais, to mine uncle's head?'

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: Amongst much other talk, that very time,

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: I heard you say that you had rather refuse

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: The offer of an hundred thousand crowns

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: Than Bolingbroke's return to England;

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: Adding withal how blest this land would be

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: In this your cousin's death.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Princes and noble lords,

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: What answer shall I make to this base man?

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Shall I so much dishonour my fair stars,

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: On equal terms to give him chastisement?

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Either I must, or have mine honour soil'd

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: With the attainder of his slanderous lips.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: There is my gage, the manual seal of death,

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: That marks thee out for hell: I say, thou liest,

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: And will maintain what thou hast said is false

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: In thy heart-blood, though being all too base

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: To stain the temper of my knightly sword.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Bagot, forbear; thou shalt not take it up.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Excepting one, I would he were the best

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: In all this presence that hath moved me so.

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: If that thy valour stand on sympathy,

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: There is my gage, Aumerle, in gage to thine:

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: By that fair sun which shows me where thou stand'st,

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: I heard thee say, and vauntingly thou spakest it

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: That thou wert cause of noble Gloucester's death.

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: If thou deny'st it twenty times, thou liest;

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: And I will turn thy falsehood to thy heart,

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: Where it was forged, with my rapier's point.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Thou darest not, coward, live to see that day.

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: Now by my soul, I would it were this hour.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Fitzwater, thou art damn'd to hell for this.

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: Aumerle, thou liest; his honour is as true

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: In this appeal as thou art all unjust;

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: And that thou art so, there I throw my gage,

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: To prove it on thee to the extremest point

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: Of mortal breathing: seize it, if thou darest.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: An if I do not, may my hands rot off

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: And never brandish more revengeful steel

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Over the glittering helmet of my foe!

speaker: Lord
text_entry: I task the earth to the like, forsworn Aumerle;

speaker: Lord
text_entry: And spur thee on with full as many lies

speaker: Lord
text_entry: As may be holloa'd in thy treacherous ear

speaker: Lord
text_entry: From sun to sun: there is my honour's pawn;

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Engage it to the trial, if thou darest.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Who sets me else? by heaven, I'll throw at all:

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: I have a thousand spirits in one breast,

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: To answer twenty thousand such as you.

speaker: DUKE OF SURREY
text_entry: My Lord Fitzwater, I do remember well

speaker: DUKE OF SURREY
text_entry: The very time Aumerle and you did talk.

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: 'Tis very true: you were in presence then;

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: And you can witness with me this is true.

speaker: DUKE OF SURREY
text_entry: As false, by heaven, as heaven itself is true.

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: Surrey, thou liest.

speaker: DUKE OF SURREY
text_entry: Dishonourable boy!

speaker: DUKE OF SURREY
text_entry: That lie shall lie so heavy on my sword,

speaker: DUKE OF SURREY
text_entry: That it shall render vengeance and revenge

speaker: DUKE OF SURREY
text_entry: Till thou the lie-giver and that lie do lie

speaker: DUKE OF SURREY
text_entry: In earth as quiet as thy father's skull:

speaker: DUKE OF SURREY
text_entry: In proof whereof, there is my honour's pawn;

speaker: DUKE OF SURREY
text_entry: Engage it to the trial, if thou darest.

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: How fondly dost thou spur a forward horse!

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: If I dare eat, or drink, or breathe, or live,

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: I dare meet Surrey in a wilderness,

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: And spit upon him, whilst I say he lies,

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: And lies, and lies: there is my bond of faith,

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: To tie thee to my strong correction.

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: As I intend to thrive in this new world,

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: Aumerle is guilty of my true appeal:

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: Besides, I heard the banish'd Norfolk say

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: That thou, Aumerle, didst send two of thy men

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: To execute the noble duke at Calais.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Some honest Christian trust me with a gage

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: That Norfolk lies: here do I throw down this,

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: If he may be repeal'd, to try his honour.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: These differences shall all rest under gage

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Till Norfolk be repeal'd: repeal'd he shall be,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And, though mine enemy, restored again

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: To all his lands and signories: when he's return'd,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Against Aumerle we will enforce his trial.

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: That honourable day shall ne'er be seen.

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Many a time hath banish'd Norfolk fought

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: For Jesu Christ in glorious Christian field,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Streaming the ensign of the Christian cross

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Against black pagans, Turks, and Saracens:

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: And toil'd with works of war, retired himself

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: To Italy; and there at Venice gave

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: His body to that pleasant country's earth,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: And his pure soul unto his captain Christ,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Under whose colours he had fought so long.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Why, bishop, is Norfolk dead?

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: As surely as I live, my lord.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Sweet peace conduct his sweet soul to the bosom

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Of good old Abraham! Lords appellants,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Your differences shall all rest under gage

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Till we assign you to your days of trial.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Enter DUKE OF YORK, attended

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Great Duke of Lancaster, I come to thee

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: From plume-pluck'd Richard; who with willing soul

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Adopts thee heir, and his high sceptre yields

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: To the possession of thy royal hand:

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Ascend his throne, descending now from him;

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: And long live Henry, fourth of that name!

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: In God's name, I'll ascend the regal throne.

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Marry. God forbid!

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Worst in this royal presence may I speak,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Yet best beseeming me to speak the truth.

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Would God that any in this noble presence

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Were enough noble to be upright judge

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Of noble Richard! then true noblesse would

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Learn him forbearance from so foul a wrong.

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: What subject can give sentence on his king?

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: And who sits here that is not Richard's subject?

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Thieves are not judged but they are by to hear,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Although apparent guilt be seen in them;

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: And shall the figure of God's majesty,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: His captain, steward, deputy-elect,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Anointed, crowned, planted many years,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Be judged by subject and inferior breath,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: And he himself not present? O, forfend it, God,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: That in a Christian climate souls refined

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Should show so heinous, black, obscene a deed!

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: I speak to subjects, and a subject speaks,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Stirr'd up by God, thus boldly for his king:

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: My Lord of Hereford here, whom you call king,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Is a foul traitor to proud Hereford's king:

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: And if you crown him, let me prophesy:

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: The blood of English shall manure the ground,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: And future ages groan for this foul act;

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Peace shall go sleep with Turks and infidels,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: And in this seat of peace tumultuous wars

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Shall kin with kin and kind with kind confound;

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Disorder, horror, fear and mutiny

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Shall here inhabit, and this land be call'd

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: The field of Golgotha and dead men's skulls.

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: O, if you raise this house against this house,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: It will the woefullest division prove

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: That ever fell upon this cursed earth.

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Prevent it, resist it, let it not be so,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Lest child, child's children, cry against you woe!

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Well have you argued, sir; and, for your pains,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Of capital treason we arrest you here.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: My Lord of Westminster, be it your charge

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: To keep him safely till his day of trial.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: May it please you, lords, to grant the commons' suit.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Fetch hither Richard, that in common view

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: He may surrender; so we shall proceed

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Without suspicion.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: I will be his conduct.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Exit

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Lords, you that here are under our arrest,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Procure your sureties for your days of answer.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Little are we beholding to your love,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And little look'd for at your helping hands.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Re-enter DUKE OF YORK, with KING RICHARD II, and Officers bearing the regalia

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Alack, why am I sent for to a king,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Before I have shook off the regal thoughts

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Wherewith I reign'd? I hardly yet have learn'd

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To insinuate, flatter, bow, and bend my limbs:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Give sorrow leave awhile to tutor me

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To this submission. Yet I well remember

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The favours of these men: were they not mine?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Did they not sometime cry, 'all hail!' to me?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: So Judas did to Christ: but he, in twelve,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Found truth in all but one: I, in twelve thousand, none.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: God save the king! Will no man say amen?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Am I both priest and clerk? well then, amen.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: God save the king! although I be not he;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And yet, amen, if heaven do think him me.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To do what service am I sent for hither?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: To do that office of thine own good will

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Which tired majesty did make thee offer,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: The resignation of thy state and crown

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: To Henry Bolingbroke.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Give me the crown. Here, cousin, seize the crown;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Here cousin:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: On this side my hand, and on that side yours.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Now is this golden crown like a deep well

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That owes two buckets, filling one another,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The emptier ever dancing in the air,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The other down, unseen and full of water:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That bucket down and full of tears am I,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Drinking my griefs, whilst you mount up on high.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: I thought you had been willing to resign.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: My crown I am; but still my griefs are mine:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: You may my glories and my state depose,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: But not my griefs; still am I king of those.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Part of your cares you give me with your crown.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Your cares set up do not pluck my cares down.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: My care is loss of care, by old care done;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Your care is gain of care, by new care won:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The cares I give I have, though given away;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: They tend the crown, yet still with me they stay.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Are you contented to resign the crown?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Ay, no; no, ay; for I must nothing be;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Therefore no no, for I resign to thee.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Now mark me, how I will undo myself;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: I give this heavy weight from off my head

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And this unwieldy sceptre from my hand,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The pride of kingly sway from out my heart;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: With mine own tears I wash away my balm,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: With mine own hands I give away my crown,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: With mine own tongue deny my sacred state,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: With mine own breath release all duty's rites:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: All pomp and majesty I do forswear;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: My manors, rents, revenues I forego;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: My acts, decrees, and statutes I deny:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: God pardon all oaths that are broke to me!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: God keep all vows unbroke that swear to thee!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Make me, that nothing have, with nothing grieved,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And thou with all pleased, that hast all achieved!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Long mayst thou live in Richard's seat to sit,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And soon lie Richard in an earthly pit!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: God save King Harry, unking'd Richard says,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And send him many years of sunshine days!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: What more remains?

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: No more, but that you read

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: These accusations and these grievous crimes

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Committed by your person and your followers

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Against the state and profit of this land;

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: That, by confessing them, the souls of men

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: May deem that you are worthily deposed.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Must I do so? and must I ravel out

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: My weaved-up folly? Gentle Northumberland,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: If thy offences were upon record,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Would it not shame thee in so fair a troop

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To read a lecture of them? If thou wouldst,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: There shouldst thou find one heinous article,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Containing the deposing of a king

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And cracking the strong warrant of an oath,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Mark'd with a blot, damn'd in the book of heaven:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Nay, all of you that stand and look upon,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Whilst that my wretchedness doth bait myself,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Though some of you with Pilate wash your hands

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Showing an outward pity; yet you Pilates

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Have here deliver'd me to my sour cross,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And water cannot wash away your sin.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: My lord, dispatch; read o'er these articles.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Mine eyes are full of tears, I cannot see:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And yet salt water blinds them not so much

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: But they can see a sort of traitors here.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Nay, if I turn mine eyes upon myself,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: I find myself a traitor with the rest;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For I have given here my soul's consent

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To undeck the pompous body of a king;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Made glory base and sovereignty a slave,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Proud majesty a subject, state a peasant.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: My lord,--

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: No lord of thine, thou haught insulting man,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Nor no man's lord; I have no name, no title,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: No, not that name was given me at the font,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: But 'tis usurp'd: alack the heavy day,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That I have worn so many winters out,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And know not now what name to call myself!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: O that I were a mockery king of snow,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Standing before the sun of Bolingbroke,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To melt myself away in water-drops!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Good king, great king, and yet not greatly good,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: An if my word be sterling yet in England,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Let it command a mirror hither straight,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That it may show me what a face I have,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Since it is bankrupt of his majesty.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Go some of you and fetch a looking-glass.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Exit an attendant

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Read o'er this paper while the glass doth come.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Fiend, thou torment'st me ere I come to hell!

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Urge it no more, my Lord Northumberland.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: The commons will not then be satisfied.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: They shall be satisfied: I'll read enough,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: When I do see the very book indeed

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Where all my sins are writ, and that's myself.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Re-enter Attendant, with a glass

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Give me the glass, and therein will I read.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: No deeper wrinkles yet? hath sorrow struck

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: So many blows upon this face of mine,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And made no deeper wounds? O flattering glass,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Like to my followers in prosperity,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Thou dost beguile me! Was this face the face

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That every day under his household roof

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Did keep ten thousand men? was this the face

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That, like the sun, did make beholders wink?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Was this the face that faced so many follies,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And was at last out-faced by Bolingbroke?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: A brittle glory shineth in this face:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: As brittle as the glory is the face;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Dashes the glass against the ground

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For there it is, crack'd in a hundred shivers.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Mark, silent king, the moral of this sport,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: How soon my sorrow hath destroy'd my face.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: The shadow of your sorrow hath destroy'd

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: The shadow or your face.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Say that again.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The shadow of my sorrow! ha! let's see:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: 'Tis very true, my grief lies all within;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And these external manners of laments

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Are merely shadows to the unseen grief

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That swells with silence in the tortured soul;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: There lies the substance: and I thank thee, king,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For thy great bounty, that not only givest

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Me cause to wail but teachest me the way

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: How to lament the cause. I'll beg one boon,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And then be gone and trouble you no more.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Shall I obtain it?

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Name it, fair cousin.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: 'Fair cousin'? I am greater than a king:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For when I was a king, my flatterers

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Were then but subjects; being now a subject,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: I have a king here to my flatterer.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Being so great, I have no need to beg.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Yet ask.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And shall I have?

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: You shall.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Then give me leave to go.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Whither?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Whither you will, so I were from your sights.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Go, some of you convey him to the Tower.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: O, good! convey? conveyers are you all,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That rise thus nimbly by a true king's fall.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Exeunt KING RICHARD II, some Lords, and a Guard

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: On Wednesday next we solemnly set down

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Our coronation: lords, prepare yourselves.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Exeunt all except the BISHOP OF CARLISLE, the Abbot of Westminster, and DUKE OF AUMERLE

speaker: Abbot
text_entry: A woeful pageant have we here beheld.

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: The woe's to come; the children yet unborn.

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Shall feel this day as sharp to them as thorn.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: You holy clergymen, is there no plot

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: To rid the realm of this pernicious blot?

speaker: Abbot
text_entry: My lord,

speaker: Abbot
text_entry: Before I freely speak my mind herein,

speaker: Abbot
text_entry: You shall not only take the sacrament

speaker: Abbot
text_entry: To bury mine intents, but also to effect

speaker: Abbot
text_entry: Whatever I shall happen to devise.

speaker: Abbot
text_entry: I see your brows are full of discontent,

speaker: Abbot
text_entry: Your hearts of sorrow and your eyes of tears:

speaker: Abbot
text_entry: Come home with me to supper; and I'll lay

speaker: Abbot
text_entry: A plot shall show us all a merry day.

speaker: Abbot
text_entry: Exeunt
